definition: much obliged/thank you/to ask advice/(ironically or humorously) to experience/to taste
neck/collar/to lead/to receive/classifier for clothes, mats, screens etc
surname Jiao
to teach
religion/teaching/to make/to cause/to tell

sentences.english: I noticed when I took my first step inside . I bumped my head on the doorframe .
sentences.chinese: 我刚踏进第一步时就领教了，我一头撞在了门框上。
对此，弗格森是领教过的。

sentences.english: Oogway may have picked you, but when l'm through with you.
sentences.chinese: 乌龟是选中了你，不过等你在我这儿领教过之后。

sentences.english: The Chinese dare to die such as return of spirit perhaps you haven't accepted?
sentences.chinese: 中国人誓死如归的精神也许你们还没领教过吧？

sentences.english: True parties of'inborn Chi Kung'only so-so, Joe's master accepted.
sentences.chinese: 真派的‘先天气功’不过如此，乔老爷领教了。

sentences.english: She has had a hard line from men before.
sentences.chinese: 男人的强硬立场，她也是领教过的。
而《1Q84》的读者早已有所领教。

sentences.english: I have tasted of his anger.
I have seen some of these bright ideas of Smith's before.
sentences.chinese: 史密斯的鬼点子我已领教过一些了。

sentences.english: Starting in 1972, we were exposed to such a Soviet steamroller.
sentences.chinese: 从一九七二年起，我们就领教了苏联这种高压手段。

sentences.english: Before Mr. Ch'u I can only humbly ask for instruction.
sentences.chinese: 在褚先生前面只能虚心领教做学生。

sentences.english: It is astonishing, after the manic energy of India and the peace is welcome.
sentences.chinese: 领教过印度疯狂的能量后，安静平和的氛围真不错。

sentences.english: For its part, the IOC has learned how scorpions behave.
sentences.chinese: 国际奥委会可是领教过蝎子是如何表现的。

sentences.english: Anyway, didn't I realized how is that particular someone like?
sentences.chinese: 反正，某人是怎么样的，我之前不就领教过了吗？

definition: to gain first-hand knowledge of sth/to experience for oneself/knowledge/experience/insight
knowing sb by their reputation can't compare to meeting them in person (idiom)
pinyin: wen2 ming2 bu4 ru2 jian4 mian4

definition: lit. name is not in vain (idiom); a fully justified reputation/enjoys a well-deserved reputation
to step down gracefully (humble expression)/to concede defeat/to play second fiddle
I have been looking forward to meeting you for a long time (idiom)
to consult/to ask for advice
honorific: I've long looked forward to meeting you./It's an honor to meet you at last.
to accept wholeheartedly/to embrace/to be won over
your name has been known to me for a long time (polite)
to have real skill/to know one's stuff
egotistical/arrogant/brassy
wise move/masterstroke/bright ideas
might/awe-inspiring authority/impressive
to compare notes/to learn from one another/to swap pointers
not more than so-so (idiom); mediocre/nothing out of the ordinary
lit. seeing others go hunting, one is excited by memories of the thrill of the hunt (idiom)/fig. seeing others do what one loves to do, one is inspired to try it again
